The initial taste one encounters is of strong espresso coffee, moving into a malty chocolate finish, with hints of the smokiness that I associate with German cooking. My only real criticism would be that it is perhaps a little watery on the palate. Nonetheless, this a wonderfully rewarding beer.

Strong malty aroma. Dark fruits, molasses. Dark brown/red in the light, medium head that lingers for a bit. Taste is brown sugar, honey, plum, molasses, raisins. Not cloying, but very sweet, rich. Full palate but not too heavy. Overall this is a great beer IMO. The "sweetest" beer I have ever tasted that is not cloying. I have not had another "heavy" beer with this much strong sweet flavor, that was still able to not completely bog you down and somehow remain almost crisp.

From the 25 fl. oz. bottle #5269.  The pour is slow with a bold sound of bubbling goodness.  The color is a dark amber with red hues and maybe a quarter inch of silky beige head.  The aroma is full of roasted malts, toffee, molasses, and even a little brown sugar. The texture of the brew is as bold as it sounds. The taste has a bitter malty sweetness with a miniscule but noted injection of hops at the tail end.  The short description is "yummy."

Bottle. Aroma is syrupy sweet with molasses and raisins. Rich deep gorgeous redish color with creamy light tan head and slight lacing. Roasted malty flavor with hints of raisin, caramel and dried cherries. Slightly sweet with a slight bitter finish. Light carbonation. Touch of alcohol on the nose. Very good...highly recommend.

500ml bottle from Central Market shared with DarkBeerChick.  Poured a glowing, inviting, deep, ruby/amber body topped with an almost ever-lasting tan head that left some nice lacing.  Aromas of ripe dark fruits, light bready malt sweetness, plums and raisins.  Flavors are in line with the aromas and add a caramel sweetness, some mild hop bitterness in the finish and a touch of alcohol.  Fine, soft carbonation with a medium mouthfeel and body.  A great widely available and decently priced doppel.

(16.9 oz bottle).  Pours dark brown with red hue and beige head.  Aroma of molasses, grass, milk chocolate.  Taste is sweet-molasses and caramel are evident.  Wonderful surprise!  Medium bodied and creamy.  This finish is slightly bitter, but smooth.  It seems to lack real depth, but it is a tasty beer and was beyond my expectations.  Excellent!

I had this after part of a bottle of Salvator. I really tried to like it but I couldnt. I kept thinking about their great Hefeweizen.  Probably not as bad as my experience but for sure nowhere near one of the best.

Bottle. Clear reddish brown pour, creamy off-white head. Aroma of brown sugar, dark malts, spices and roasted malts. Flavor is sugary sweet with some caramel and some smoke. Slightly bitter finish. Creamy texture, average carbonation.

Bottle. Aroma is fresh caramel, burnt sugar, candied dates and butterscotch. 
Appearance is dark brown with a half inch of milky light brown head. Taste begins with rich caramel and toasted malt flavors followed by brown sugar, spice bread, molasses and raisins. Mouthfeel is syrupy and full-bodied with medium carbonation and a dry finish. This is an incredibly rich and malty brew that should pair quite well with smoked meats as well as desserts.
Bottle 500ml. Color black with medium lasting head. Aroma caramel, smoke.  Taste roasted malt, chocolate, sweet caramel. Great Doppelbock.
Pours a cola black color in glass. Nose is butterscotch, rum barrel, toffee, light licorice and star anise. Taste is butterscotch toffee and roasted malts and barley.

Aroma: This lagers aroma is undoubtedly that of a German Doppelbock. There is a maple syrup quality that is accented with caramelized malts and a slight smoke character. The nose on this is very complex and rich. With a mild swirl notes of dried figs and prunes emerge to compliment the malt. I think I can find just the faintest hint of herbal spice.
Appearance: A gorgeous reddish dark brown which retains its translucence when held up to the light. The head was glorious when fist poured and has retained a thick, tan foam across the surface of the beer. 
Taste/Palate: So, for a doppelbock this lager is surprisingly light bodied. Not to take away anything from the extreme complexity of the beer, just noticing that it retains the lightness of body to be easily drinkable. The first sip reveals a rich, roasty and somewhat sweet lager. Upon further inspection the dried fruit character shoots fourth with some of that maple and caramel. The best thing about drinking this lager is the bitter finish. The roasted malt and light hops come together in the finish to clean up the palate and refresh the mouth. That is what makes this beer feel so light to drink. The aftertaste lingers forever and really grows in texture and flavor. Im continuing to get bitter chocolate and coffee flavors mixed with herbal toffee. This beer is a great after dinner treat! 
Overall: Many doppelbocks have I tried and been made almost sick from the left over sugar sweetness. I am happy to report that this beer is well balanced! Im a fan of all beer. The darker ales and lagers have been loosing favor with me in recent years because I just have not had the will to drink the heavy muck the "big beer" brewers have been putting out lately. This beer has garnered a special place in my book of tasty things and might lead me down the road of dark once again.

Pours an enticing dark brown color with little head.  Aroma of roasted malt and caramel.  Flavor has roasted malts, caramel, chocolate and nuts.   Light body for a beer that looks heavy.  Very nice beer!

500ml Bottle  Gravity Beer Market  Olympia, WA
Aroma  Nice dark malt aroma with sweet caramel in the  aroma.  
Appearance  Brown in color, Hazy with a thin head.   
Flavor   Wonderful malt with good roast and caramel and light chocolate flavors.  
Palate    Dry finish with a Nice Mouthfeel. 
Overall  One awesome Doppelbock

Pours a dark brown with big creamy tan head and lots of great malty aroma that has hints of caramel, roast, toast and hay.  Flavor follows in a similar fashion with no bitterness and plenty of darker malts.  Heavy bodied but drinks smooth and finishes almost crisp.

Clear nutty brown body, tanned head. Looks like a doppebock. Fruity and nutty aroma, some sugary notes. Little roasted and some alcohol. Sweet lots of sugars with some roasted flavour and alcohol. Too much alcohol in flavour. Sweet but metallic mouthfeel.

Aroma - Didnt really have much of an initial aroma. Light notes of nuts, but aside from that not much for the nose.

Appearance - Absolutely stunning. Pours like Dr. Pepper, looks like a Stout, but when held up to the light has a brilliant amber color. Very similar in color to a Fat Tire when held up to light.

Taste - Wow. Hits with biscuits, bananas, and almost a copper, velvety feel.

Palate - After you swallow, there is a definite floral hoppy after taste that lasts for three to five seconds. Then it billows out into a strong malty taste.

Overall - Probably one of the best beers Ive ever had. Very complex in its taste, and goes great with German food.

clear dark brown, smooth light brown head with some white areas. looks great. head disappears pretty quickly though
malty, bitter malty, nutty, caramelly aroma.
flavor is sweet caramelly, bitter caramelly, malty, nutty, bitter nutty. nicely packaged together with a non-cloying sweet malty base. Pretty tasty.

I am not usually a fan of this style, but this beer really just nails it.  It is so balanced and smooth and sweet, without being overbearingly so.    Its doughy with a bit of spice, near full bodied, and just so easy going and pleasant and flawless.  Brilliant.

Bottle as shown. Pours a dark amber with a mdeium creamy beige head that leaves decent spotty lacing. The aroma is a swet fruity malt with raisin and licorice. Medium mouthfeel with a rich malt and smoke with a nice lingering finish. Hides the alcohol well making it easy to drink, a very good Doppelbock from BSW.

Bottle sample at homebrew meeting. Pours a medium brown with tannish head. Nose is not as robust as Celebrator. Pick out dark breads, a bit of caramel, maybe a kiss of dark fruit. Taste is a bit dryer than I had expected with more bready notes. Chewy mouthfeel. Pretty damn nice.

Pours a three-finger very light tan head that fades quickly to a ring leaving some lace.  Deep brown color with some mahogany highlights.  Medium bodied and light-medium carbonation.   Nose is roasted malt.  Flavor is malt and sweet molasses. $3.15 for a 500ml bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, MA.
Draft at redlight redlight.  Cloudy brown.  Aroma of apples and bananas and yeast. Flavor is bready and less fruity than one would expect.

Bottle 13C. Mahogany with a light tan head. Complex dark malty aroma has dates, figs, prunes and chocolate. Taste is restrained dark fruity sweetness. Fantastic creamy texture. Mild roast and a bit of wood at the end. Oozes class, but just a tad too sweet for me.
19 ounce bottle-a dark brown pour-tan fluffy head-aroma and taste of caramel, bread, dough, nuts, -sweet brown sugar toasty finish

0.5 l bottle from Alko. Dark ruby color. Malty and bready aroma with toffee, caramel, almonds and raisins. Sweet toffeish malty flavor with nuts, raisins and figs. Full bodied. Rich taste with good dark fruit character. At first this feels too bready but as the carbonation dissipates and the beer warms, breadiness fades and dark fruits kick in.

Bottle shared by a friend. Clear brown pour with a medium beige head. Caramel malt nose with a grainy character and lager yeast. Caramel malt flavor with lager yeast, nuts and a bit of roast in the finish.

Shared with multiple others at brew club. Pours a thin off white head, without lacing, over a dark amber (SRM 15) clear body....nose is light molasses, brown sugar.....taste is sweet with light malts and minimal bitterness.....mouth feel is light, carbonation medium. This is a light  Dopplebock. It is not unpleasant, just light.  Tasting of 2/26/10.   BJCP 7/3/11/4/6
Excellent beer. rich with flavor dark brown with a beige head. Worth every cent

Pours reddish dark brown with beige head; sweet malty, bready aroma with notes of buttery caramel and rye pudding; quite full-bodied and smooth; malty sweet flavor with actually quite complex notes of rye bread, caramel, roastedness and a balancing dark berry-like finish.
Bottle. Great dark, purpleish pour with thin bubbly head. Dark foamy body with bright, sweet malt head, spices and anise. Body is a big malt bomb with huge round, filling flavor. Awesome full doppel.

poured from a 16.9oz. bottle into a Guinness stout glass.  Poured a deep dark ebony color, not as dark as a Guinness, but a full colored body.  Head foam was light tan that faded to a nice lacing on top.  

Smell was pleasing and sweet, but light without an overpowering feel to it.

Taste was great with a pleasant but again not overpowering sweet caramel/bready/malty goodness. 

Nice enjoyable big beer.  One of the better Doppelbocks around.

500 ml bottle. Finland.
Dark reddish brown colour with small light tan head.
Roasted malty aroma with sweet brown sugar and mild hops.
Sweet sugary and roasted malty flavour with some hops.
Rich malty Doppelbock, like it should.
.5L bottle - Shared w/ SkyCop32. Picked up at Maruhn Getränke in Darmstadt. Pours a nice dark brown. Aroma of malt, nuts, hops. Tastes malty, with some hops and roasty hints.
On tap at The Taphouse, pours dark reddish brown. Aroma and flavour of roasted malts, toffee and brown sugar. Very nice.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2017 Pours dark red with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted malts with some peanuts, Flavor is quite expected roasted malts. A bit watery. (747212)
(110317) Re-rate from a bottle. Better than I claimed before. Quality stuff.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 1pt. 0.9oz bottle into my big Spaten Oktoberfest Stange glass. There is no freshness date on the label but it has a bottle number of 3438 printed on the back.

Appearance: The body has a dark brown color with lighter brownish red highlights. On top sits a nice light tan head which was about two fingers thick right after it was poured. This head slowly fades but hangs on till the last sip, (not that it took me long it get there lol). There was some nice slick lacing, as well, which slid right down the glass as I drank.

Smell: The aroma is pleasing and sweet with notes of dark sweet bread, cooked or burnt sugar, as well as some mellow notes of over ripe fruit and classic German hops.

Taste/Palate: It has a firm, slick, full bodied palate with a flavor profile that matches its aroma. The flavor is full dark sweet bready malty goodness. There are some hints of nuts and fruit mixed into the mostly sweet malt along with some decent leafy/spicy, almost earthy hops for balance. The hops also add a nice balance to the finish making it quite drinkable.

Notes: This is a very enjoyable and drinkable big beer. Just look out for the solid 7.4% abv. that will sneak up on you.

Pours out a deep ruby red, strong toffee and dried fruit scent.  Dried fruit flavor with a hint of coffee at the end with bitterness in the aftertaste.  Definitely heavier than Weihenstephans weizens, yet another winner.

06/03 0.5 l bottle at brewerys outlet in Berlin. It poured clear dark brown reddish body with medium sized brown head. Very sweet malty aroma, I would say sticky, like berry jam, caramel and brown sugar, nice. Flavor is slightly balanced with some nice coffee, but of course, sugary and caramel malt are still dominating. Licorice and maybe even some herbal hops are present. Full bodied, sticky texture. Long sweet finish with only a hint of alcohol. Very nice doppelbock although not really my style. What two nice beers we just had here at Weihenstephaners!

pours reddish- brown with a rich tan head. Strong dark fruit aroma, prunes, raisins, a bit of caramel. low carbonation, medium-full body. bitter to the taste, a bit rough on the palate. Taste has prunes, roasted, nutty flavors. not really my cup of tea, or beer. w/e.

Flaske 0,5l kjøpt fra Alko Muonio. Dyp rød på farge. OK lysebrunt skum som imidlertid flatet nesten helt ut. Søt maltaroma. Smaken er også søt malt med innslag av ristet malt etterhvert. Godt balansert. Litt bitterhet i ettersmaken. Avslutter tørt. KI=8

Extremely fine. Dark brown clear pour with reddy tinge and tan head. Smell barnyard and creamy sweet malts. Taste same with some vanilla and biscuit and a bit of wild flower honey and barnyard. VERY Aromatic doppel! The presence of dark malts and hops in this is very prominent yet balanced, a German classic.

Bottle. Pours deep brown with ruby highlights. Huge sweet aroma with caramel and molasses. Substantial palate with low carbonation. Very smooth. Sip slowly due to the heft and sweetness. Sweet caramel/molasses flavor as well as some dark fruits. Very nice.

Pours out a ruby brown color with a moderate off white head. Aroma is sweet and of some dried fruits and a light roast note. Taste is complex, roasted malt, sweet dried fruits (plum, raisin), and some interesting earthy notes. Not always my style, but this was pretty solid.

Bottle 500ml. Pours a dark red/brown color with a medium creamy beige head. Low to medium carbonation and full body. The aroma is sweet and roasted malt, dark caramel, but also spicy and some notes of dark fruits. It has a smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Malty and dry finish with a little bitterness.

Bottle. Dark ruby with a medium-sized beige head. Malty aroma with hints of dark fruits. The flavour is sweet and malty with notes of dark fruits and liquorice. Medium to full-bodied, not much bitterness. Quite good doppelbock.

17 oz. bottle.  Pours a very deep maroon, looks brown but behind light its a dark red, with a nice red-tan head.  Malty aroma, slightly spicy, aroma of smoked meat, but not dominating.  Amazing palate, very silky smooth.  Taste is very slightly smokey, with notes of roast malts.  This one is just good - would be a great, great session.

At the Weihenstephaner at the Hackesher Markt, Berlin. Poured a very dark red body with a tan head that went away at a relatively slow pace. Oily dark malty nose, raisins, strawberry jam, quite subtle and very nice. Sweet malty taste, somewhat strange but nice, light caramel, balanced with a tiny bitterness coming more from hops than from the roastiness. Light notes of chocolate. Very nice and definitely my type of doppelbock. Alcohol? Where?

Bottled. Pours clear dark brown with quickly diminshing, large, creamy off-white head. Taste is lightly bitter. Palate has a full body, creamy texture and average carbonation. Aromas have caramel, hint of nutty malts, herbs, berries.

Dark, deep ruby to brown coloured beer. Medium-sized head is creamy and lacy. The aroma is darkis fruity (dates, rasins) with some sweeter apricot. Good amount of bready maltiness and some dark caramel. Light hoppiness and some licorice in the finish. Mellow roastedness, milk chocolatey finish. The flavor is sweet, like liquid bread. Light, milk sugary sourness and saltiness of licorice. Full bodied palate, low carbonation and velvety texture. Overall it is strong but very well balanced and surprisingly mellow and smooth at the same time.

50cl bottle. Pours dark brown/reddish colour with a small beige head. Aroma is kinda sweet of roasted malts. Flavour is very well balanced, sweet malty and caramel, finish is long with a little taste of alcohol. Smooth and very enjoyable. Excellent doppelbock!

deep, dark brown with a thick khaki head.  nose is sweet chocolate malts, slight caramel, and a hint of syrup.  smooth on the palate with the sweet chocolate malts taking over at first followed by a syrupy, bready finish.

500 ml bottle. Deep dark ruby colour, medium-sized beige head. Sweetish aroma of roasted malts and dark fruits. The flavour is roasted, sweet (but not too sweet), with roasted malts, dark fruits and some alcohol wamth. Full-bodied and smooth.

0,5 l bottle. Nice deep red color, little head. Aroma is malty, with a touch of smoked ham and even soy sauce. Flavor is quite complex with smoked tones, chocolate and roasted malts perhaps the most dominating features. All in all, a very good Doppel Bock.

Malty smoked wood aroma with a doughy yeast kick. Pours a very dark ruby red, with a nice head, slightly tinted chocolate. Very smooth, sweet palate and a nice kick of smokeyness. Malt dominates this beer with a unique chocolate, smokey taste. Good beer
Bottle from Alko. Very dark, reddish colour. Surypy malty aroma. A bit sweet taste is very malty and a bit hoppy in the end. Well balanced, medium to full body. A good one definitely!

Dark, reddish brown beer quite big, beige head. Aroma is quite mild, syrup, malts, roasted malts, some raisins. Flavour is nicely balanced, malty, roasted malts that balanced sweetness, some bitterness and sourness. Smooth and great, full-bodied beer to drink. Succesful, balanced beer, not so sweet as many beer within this style; definedly worth to try.

Deep reddish brown, soft brown head. Aroma wasnt very strong. Beer was quite cold early on, but the aroma didnt intensify very much even after warming up, maybe its just my nose acting up. What little there was, sweet maltiness dominated the aroma. Mouthfeel was superbly smooth and even creamy. Flavor was nice and sweet without being annoyingly syrupy. Overall an excellent brew.

500mL bottle.  Pours a syrupy clear dark red with a thick light brown head.  Strong aroma of dried fruit with caramel and a little roastiness.  Quite sweet and fruity, with some roasty flavours, a little biscuity, and the alcohol is noticeable.  Carbonation on the low side, full bodied and slick with a slight astringency and increasing bitterness in the finish.
UPDATED: NOV 30, 2012 Bottle. Nice Flavor. Malty tones of caramel and toasty, nutty, coffee accents. Aroma of malts and spicy hopps accent. Nice pour. Solid performer.

Pours with a deep red-brown body topped by a medium thick head with a good amount of lacing on the glass.  Its sweet and malty with light toffee and caramel notes and a barely there bitterness.  Full bodied and smooth.
Pours dark brown with ample head. Great malty nose. Roasted malty, fruity, flavors with short finish. Gets a little cloying about halfway through the pint.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.  Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights and fluffy tan head.  Taste is toasted malt, some chocolate, and a little smoke.  Good beer just not quite as good as Celebrator.

Pours a huge 2 finger beige head. Body is dark brown in color, lots of bubbles rising throughout. Head retention and lacing are above average

Aroma is of roasted malt and dried prunes. Hops and alcohol arent present.

Taste is of roasted malts and lots of dried fruit. Has that unique dopplebock flavor definitely in there. Hops arent detected and alcohol is faint. After taste is of candied sugar and simple syrup

Mouthfeel is good. Carbonation is on the light side. Head contributes a little to this medium bodied beer.

Drinkability is good. For over 7 percent its almost sessionable. Its just a little on the bland side. It might be old since it traveled a long way to get to me and theres no dating on the bottle. Worth the price since its rather cheap but wouldnt be my first choice

Malty smoked wood aroma with a doughy yeast kick.  Pours a very dark ruby red, with a nice head, slightly tinted chocolate.  Very smooth, sweet palate and a nice kick of smokeyness. Malt dominates this beer with a unique chocolate, smokey taste.  Good beer that probably pairs with food better than by itself.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2012 Bottle 500ml from Parkhill cellars. Great beer, smooth like a fine wine, complex like the best beers. Aromas of burnt caramel, toffee, plum, alcohol, and hints of butter. Taste is sweet, with subtle bitter notes, and long lasting. Palate is syrupy and full-bodied. Dark brown, with a thin frothy head.

(bottle from Queen Liquor in Colorado Springs). Clear ruby color. Medium tan head. Very light malt aroma. Light sweet caramel flavor. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.

Pours super dark brown with beautiful garnet hues. The head is creamy beige in color, beginning around the size of a finger, and quickly dissipating to a veneer/ring. The aroma is beautifully malt accentuated- roasted barley, raisin, plum, fig, date, chocolate, and some subtle notes of smoke. Vinous booze also abounds. The flavor is a massively sweet concoction of dark fruit, chocolate, and dark sugar. Cocoa nib, milk chocolate, brown sugar, plum, roasted barley, and further smoke notes. The palate is quite full, with a caressing mouthfeel, and low to medium effervescence. The finish is dryish- both from booze and a roast induced chalky feel. Damn fine...

Pours a dark garnet/ruby with a light beige head that dissipates fairly quickly. Aroma holds massive quantities of fig, plum, raisin, chocolate, brown sugar, red wine, caramel, and some nice smoky undertones; really nice sweetness on the nose overall. Flavor is chocolate galore, along with more of the great dark malt sweetness, including molasses and vanilla extract. Palate is medium bodied, but with an intriguingly high amount of dryness of the finish that would presumably come from the alcohol and roast. Really nice brew overall; doesnt quite catch Celebrator, but a damn good doppelbock.

Bottle (in NZ). Pours a dark cola-brown with a brown foamy head. Toasted malt nose with caramel and chocolate. Deliciously smooth malty palate, drinks very easily for 7.4%. The flavours are a little understated at first, but really come through later in the swallow. A mix of milk and dark chocolate and a little bit smokey. Would happily drink a lot of this.

Dark red-brown with a fluffy tan head. Very mild and pleasant aroma, lots of caramel and honey. I might even call it floral. Flavor is again mild, but extremely pleasant and drinkable. Not too bitter, and a nice balanced sweetness. Very light and airy on the palate. An absolute pleasure to drink.

Pours the color of diet coke, without the foam and fizz.  A very quiet-pouring brew.  Aroma is faint, of anise, barley, malt (caramel and hay).  Flavor is pretty richly of sweet resin hops, a touch of citrus, some bittersweet anise, and some toasty nuttiness.  A nicely complex brew.  Thanks for the recommendation MrBunn!

Serving: 500 ml bottle.
It pours with a deep amber color with a frothy tan head.  This one has excellent head retention.  A big, malty nose reveals notes of wood,  molasses, brown sugar, and tobacco.  Quite nice!  The taste mirrors the nose quite a bit.  Lots of tobacco, caramel malt, raisin, oak, and perhaps a bit of smoke.  It has sort of a odd woodsy bitterness and light nut notes as well.  A bit too much wood in fact.  Medium bodied with smooth carbonation and a medium rich mouthfeel.  Malt forward with a bit of alcohol, it is a solid example of the style.  As much as it has going for it, its just too muc malt woody malt for me.
Dark brown-red, khaki colored foam.  Aroma is nutty, sweet malts, cocoa, thinning alc.  Taste is more cocoa, caramel, heavy bready, sweet malts, creamy.

From  bottle into a 20oz plaster stein.  Pours dark brown with a sumptuous head.  Aroma is all molasses with a bit of dampness to it.  Taste is a lush array of earthy notes as with brown sugar and lots of malt especially as it developes.  Low carbonation but still nice.  Finishes smooth with a big malt aftertaste.  Very tasty beer and very representative of the style.

A beautiful looking doppelbock. Dark and with a small frothy head. Taste is a little on the sweet side but is very thick and creamy. Best German bock Ive had so far, first sip isnt special but then it starts to grow for quite a while.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a big head and solid lacing. Tastes like apple juice with some smoked malts in there. Great beer.

Pours medium brown darkening to a deep brown/black. Thin head with little retention. Very malty on the nose. Kind of coffee flavor, no bitterness or not much detectable. Thick smooth body with low carbonation.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2010 Bottle from the Dallas Ginger Man. Dark ruby pour with rosy touches. Has a dark musty smell with the same smell as you drive south on 35W passing the Miller plant next door to Mrs. Bairds bakery. Taste is very bready. Has a kind of birthday cake aftertaste. This is weird as hell and Im not feelin it. 2.7
RE-RATE 11/5/10 Bottle courtesy of Fratto. Hazy brown pour with a small tannish head. Aroma is woody with dark fruits and raisins. Flavor is dark caramel. Like the caramel candies you pass up at Halloween. Easy finish.

500-ml bottle Marcellos Lafayette, LA - Aroma: sweet, raisin, toffee, caramel (malt); Appearance: hazy, garnet-brown color, frothy tan head, some laces; Flavor: sweet, salty, chocolate, caramel, toffee (malt); Mouthfeel: full bodied, creamy texture, lively carbonation; Overall: well structured, full bodied malty palate featuring a harmonious balance between sweet, chocolate, toffee malt with hints of smoke and a drying bitterness that propels the beer into a beatutiful long malty finish.

Bottle.  Cloudy brown pour with a medium tan head.  Aroma of caramel, faint yeast and malt.  Great medium to full bodied taste of caramel, roasted malt and bread.  Nice even finish that completely masks the alcohol.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2011 Multiple times in bottle and tap

§lct-mhgy, §head, sweet malty aroma, §co2, full body, smooth, §fruity malt T1, mnrl-roast-malt T2, no T3.  sweet and a bit cloying alone. malt profile is very dark and complex and enjoyable.

16.9 ounce bottle - $2.99 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours a clear, very dark reddish-brown body with a foamy, bubbly, light beige head.

Smell: Deep, dark breadiness marked by some slight roast undertones. Minor hints of cocoa, dark fruits, and nuts. Smells a bit like that American single-slice pumpernickel bread you occasionally find wrapped in plastic.

Taste: Presents a pleasant taste of powdered, unsweetened chocolate and viciously crushed cola nuts sprinkled atop a thick piece of crusty, very dark bread. Modestly sweet. Lightly fruity taste of plums dunked in simple syrup. Mild bitterness midway with a touch of dried herbs. Finishes very smooth with the dark breadiness giving way to a bit more fruit and just a touch of alcohol warmth.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium-light carbonation. Rather smooth mouthfeel.

Drinkability: A bit darker, lesser alcoholic and fruity than many doppelbocks out there -- I dug it! I mean, theres only so much alcohol and fruit a man really needs, right?

Dark cola color with an off white head that thins but lasts around the edge of the glass.  Nose is raisin with carmelized sugar.  Roasty taste but very drinkable.  Good palate, slightly oily.  Overall a very good beer.
Pours dark brown with minimal white head.  Aroma of malt and caramel.  Tastes greatly of malt, molasses, and small hint of roast.

Nice beer, fruity aroma with burnished raisin and slight coffee notes!
well balanced, nice finish

500ml bottle, Bier des Monats at Weihenstephaner Berlin am Hackeschen Markt. Very nice deep, mahogany body with a fading tan head. Smell of dark berries and bready malts. A bit of everything in the taste profile. Half-way sweet, dark bready malts in fine interplay with dried fruits, raisin and prunes, and the smooth tartness of blackcurrant to the finish. Well bodied and balanced. Clean tasting. Strong and elegant. Definitely my best one during a short week in Berlin, and one of my best German beers ever (Berlin, 23.11.2009).

Aroma is rich and malty with a sweet but not cloying undertone rather like cinnamon rolls. It pours a very appetizing semi-translucent mahogany with a fairly thick and somewhat persistent pale tan head. Aroma is malty with just a bit of hop bitterness and a hint of spice, mainly cinnamon, plus just a touch of fruit. Texture is tingly, fizzy and lively, downright lip-smacking.

500 ML Bottle in USA. Pours dark reddish-brown, with a moderate head, that dissipated somewhat quickly. Aroma is raisiny sweet. Flavor was also sweet, raisins again with molasses. There were some rum flavor undertones going on as well. There was a slight alcoholic flavor which probably contributed to me thinking of rum. A great Bock!!!!!!!
Tap at Lemmys, Leiden: Very dark brown Doppelbock wich name not end with -ator. With fruity notes, hints of caramel, chocoltae and honey.

Bottle. This is a very brown beer - dark, but not totally opaque. The foamy tan head is very nice. Nose is very caramelly, malty, a little bready, and a honey/molasses note, too. Sweet like dates/figs. I even notice a little tobacco note. Flavor is stacked - big and malty, yet with a very nice depth to it. More fruity notes, a little chocolate, and a nice little touch of noble hops. Really a very nice German brew. I could see this going really well with some rouladen and potato dumplings. Even better, cook the rouladen in the beer... Ill have to try that sometime. In any case, this ones a real pleasure to drink.

bottle....beautiful deep ruby pour , thin beige head ,some wispy lace. Sweet aroma of fruit and roasted malts . Sweet malt flavor , with notes of wood , chocolate and faint smoke. Well balanced and smooth. Medium bodied with light carbonation. Slight alcohol warmth, finish is dry .
Deep brown colour. Smell: sweet malt. Taste is sweet and malty with caramel. A very nice doppelbock.

This pours a beautiful, deep red garnet color with golden brown highlights. Three finger head of light brown foam sits on top. Really good retention and great, sticky lacing.

Good god, that has got to be be richest, maltiest smelling brew Ive had in awhile. Big, rich malts with thick gourmet caramel. Loads of brown sugar and a big dallop of black strap molasses. Dates and figs are here, also. Slight hint of tobacco. Slight yeasty, breadlike notes.

Big molasses presence, tastewise. Sweet, yet dark and dry. Nice level of maltiness makes its presence known. Very slight alcohol presence. Like the nose, you get a taste of tobacco. Caramel apples. Nice taste of black bread. Notes of dates and cherries.

Sadly, this is only a medium bodied beer. A nice, big, full body would make this one an extremely lush brew. Carbonation is a bit too crisp and therefore, short. Would benefit from smoother carbonation, as it would help it be so much more creamy.

Very drinkable, in general. The rich sweetness would keep you from throwing too many back in a single sitting, though.
I want more of this one.

Pours a nice, dark petrified amber with glimmers of red, a once frothy full head sinks to outline a pacman like creature.  The nose is bready yet with underlying fruitiness akin to cherries with some spicy pumpernickel bread and lightly toasted grains.  Body seems a bit thin at colder temps but fills out somewhat as it warms.. toasted grains, bread, and a bit of cherry ride along the flavor profile.  Has a decent bready crispness, but it lay upon too thin of a palate, even at warmer temps I think the flavors seem to get lost and disappear quite rapidly.  With more body, the flavors would be more pronounced...theyre good flavors, theyre just not pronounced enough.
Very malty, roasted flavor. Very little hop aroma. Nice caramel flavor. Good doppelbock.

Bottle enjoyed on a cloudy summer day. I have had this beer a handful of times, but I just got around to rating it now. Pours a cola-like brown color with a lot of mahogany tints and a small khaki head that disappears quickly. The aroma is very subtle. It has a roasty smell with a hint of sweet malt. It is extremely easy to drink and keeps you wanting more. It has a very roasty flavor with hints of sweet malt and caramel. Finishes very smooth. Overall, a very good beer and one of the best doppelbocks I have had to date.
dark deep brown color with almost no head, big sweet malt nose, dark fruit and maple, sweet flavor but not at all cloying, dark fruits, mild roast, dries off a bit at the end.

This is a nice, interesting doppelbock. The flavor is complex and warming and the palate is thick and luscious. The flavor has lots of bread, caramel, nuts, raisins and even wood. My main complaint is that its all a little too sweet for me. Some more bitterness would be very nice here.
On tap at Café Hesp, Amsterdam. Brown coloured, small brown head, dry slight roasted nose. Sweet malty, caramel and toffee with some woody notes in the finish. Some dried fruits also. Overrated beer.
Bottle. Dark brown with a big, tan head. Solid malty and nutty aroma followed by nutty and malty flavours. Well-balanced. Full-bodied. Craftmanship galore.

Bottle poured into Weihenstephan glass. Pours black/brown with ruby transparency and decent foamy beige head. Nose is sweet caramel and toffee malt. Taste is very smooth and sweet buttery caramel with sweet toffee tones and some faint plum and raisin hints. Excellent flavor and mouthfeel. Im liking this style more and more, and this is one of the best in it.
Pours a deep dark and completely opaque Amber with a small head.  Flavor that balances they sweet malt and fruity flavors with a little note of bread and roasted nuts.

Bottle. Pours like syrup into the glass. Brown, nutty color that is thick and creates a thick foamy off white head. Nose is very nutty, lacking sweetness, but a nice toasty malt note is to be had. Palate is less syrupy then the pour and provides a nice fizz and dry finish. Flavors are toasty malts with a nice nutty flavor and a clean dry finish.
Pours a dark ruby red. Smells of raisins, plums and sweet bread, taste follows nose. Sweet with a good finish. Very nice.

Deep ruby red color with a viscous tan head, beautiful pour. Nice roasty nutty, yeasty earthy sweet dark bread aromas. Medium body with light carbonation. Big malty, flavors are lightly sweet with toasted toffee, rich toasted multi grain bread (Miltons) with seeds and nuts. Mild warmth in the finish. Great Doublebock,
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Poured a dark amber brown with a big foam head. Lots of fruit on the nose, very sweet  and fruity on the tongue, If a bit muted. Quite a bit of carbonation. A solid doppel, but there are better examples of the style out there. Love the artwork though. Classic!

Bottle. Pours ruby with a large tanned head. Sweet malts and toffee dominate the nose. The flavour is sweet malt, caramel, toffee and dark fruit. Theres stickiness in the mouthfeel and also a light warmth from the alcohol with more sweet maltiness coming through in the finish. A classic doppelbock.

Bottle, 50cl. Nice print on the bottle. Dark red brown coloured, small quick vanishing head. Aroma is roasted malts, caramel, coffee, its  strong in the nose. Tastes bitter, malty, full bodied, good balance, although you taste athe alcohol slightly dominating. Nice.

This doppelbock is excellent, with plenty of character, yet great balance and drinkability.

Dark red-brown, it has a creamy tan head that shrinks very slowly to a thin foamy top and leaves a little lace.

The aroma is toasted whole wheat bread, scorched raisiny syrup, and hints of wood, hay, and grain.

The taste has firm, complex character but is smooth and very pleasant.  It has prunes, wood, raisins, whole wheat toast, and some spice. The sweetness is firm but balanced with toasty, peppery-spicey bitterness that takes over at the finish.
Bomber, in snifter. Orange-red-brown clear color, very dark.  Strong aroma with a subtle blend of sweet booze and molasses.  Thin, beige head that sticks to the lips. Great after-dinner brew.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2014 Draft at Qbrick 9/2009
Appearance: Dark brown
Aroma: Molasses, caramel, coffee
Flavor: Caramel,
Palate: Rich, full-mouth feel without excessive heaviness.
Comment: I didnt detect a lot of complexity, though that may have been as I had this near the end of the evening.  Still, it is delicious.

Bottle at Goro.  4/2014
Aroma: roasted, malty grain, bread, cocoa and cola.
Palate: soft and smooth.
Flavor: bready, touch of coffee/burnt grain, light bitterness on the finish.
Id rate this a 38-39 on this day.

Draught at Q-Brick in Osaka. 
Lovely reddish brown color. Chewy, meal-like aroma of oatmeal, cereals, chocolate and biscuits. Amaxingly complex malt, with chocolate, caramel, raisins and lots of dried fruit. Creamy, smooth, chewy mouth with superbly soft malts. Fantastic.

Bottle. Pours a deep dark brown with a ruby tint. Medium tan head, nice lacing. Really funky aroma of figs, malt, and slight alcohol. Flavor is typical doppelbock, not that its a bad thing. Great balance of roasted malts and chocolate, fruity sweetness. Good earthy notes. Full bodied, warming mouthfeel. A bit of a burnt aftertaste. A delicious beer. Im really starting to like doppelbocks a lot more.
A deliciously spicy and malty beer. Tastes heavily of caramelised bread pudding with a dusting of cinnamon. Mouthfeel is thick and comforting, but the hop balance saves it from being cloying.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2011 A very tasty darker beer.  Higher alcohol content, 7.4% alcohol, the alcohol taste is not strong.  Nice dark appearance.  Good mouth feel.  Decently tasty beer. (9/12/2009)
Location/Date:Rerate- bottle on November 18, 2011.
Appearance: Pours a dark brown 
Aroma:Super malty and caramely aroma.
Taste: Roastly malt, light bitterness, malt finish
Palate:Medium body, smooth, lingering aftertaste.
Summary: A really nice beer, a heavier german beer that is kind of the german version of the porter. Enjoyable.

Delicious looking dark brown pour. foamy and frothy tan head and lots of it. Slight alcohol nose with nuts and a bit of malt. Very smooth mouth feel. sweet nutty flavor with a balanced alcohol flavor. hard to put this one down. Sits very nicely on the palate with just a hint of alcohol.

Pours ruby/copper with a large persistent creamy head.
Strong sweet malt with a bit of Vegemite (not good!), some toasty notes. A hint of noble hops and some light caramel and chocolate.
Very similar flavours: sweet toasty malt, light noble hops, some toasty notes. Sweet alcohol in the finish is rather cloying.
Good rich body, but needs more carbonation to dry out the finish a bit.
This is a great brew for the money! Not as good as Celebrator, kinda Celebrator light....

Very fine dark pour with little flashes of red highlights.  Refreshing aroma features a light, malty sweetness and hops.  This is a crisp, malty bock that is nicely balanced between brown ale like malt and zesty, nutty hops, plus a dash of bourbonesque sweetness.  A very fine bock from Weihenstephaner.
Poured dark reddish brown, creamy,  chocolate,  roasted malts, molasses,  caramel, little dark fruits, slight coffee.

sweet roasty molasses flavor - bitterness at the end. feel on the tongue is creamy-great slurping, less so simply sipping. smells like bananas. I think I really like dopplebocks. I could only drink a bit of this, but while its happening, so good.
Dark brown with a medium tan head.  It has a sweet, malt and caramel aroma.  Molasses and mild coffee taste with a creamy texture and a lively roasted finish.  A very good doppelbock.

Bottle. Pours very dark brown with a nice, lasting off-white head. Aroma is a little odd having malt and chocolate up front but with a salty, seaweedy smell as well. Smooth, creamy palate sits well with flavours of toffee, dates, raisins and a bit of chocolate. Not very sweet though. A good doppelbock, unsure about the nose though, but still a very good example of the style.

Deep brown color with ruby hues.  Appears to be clear.  Impressive light beige head, leaving nice ring lace.

Smells of stew meat, caramel and sweet chocolate--not exactly attractive, but it is fascinating.  Ive never smelled this combination before in a beer.  Complex.

Rich flavor in a thin body--well not that thin, but certainly less than most bocks (not to mention doppels).  Very complex--quite dry for the style (a touch of sugar on the tongue only on the initial sip).  Surprisingly hoppy in the swallow which lingers throughout the aftertaste.  Some chocolate notes without any burnt flavors at all.  Almost like ice cream.
Bottle pours dark brown with a tiny off white head. Aroma is rich and malty with hints of dark fruit Flavor is toasted bread, caramel malt, light roasted malt finish.

Pours a deep mahogany color with no head and a lot of bubbles along the side of the glass -  looks like soda. Aroma is sweet and malty - caramel and molasses. Taste is the same plus plum, wood, and a touch of soy sauce. Alcohol is undetectable, and the mouth feel is solid. Drinkable and enjoyable - good brew.
Overall a decent dopplebock by a good brewery, but it was a bit hot for me.  Should maybe age another bottle for a bit.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown color with a light off-white head.  A hint of fig and cherry with a mostly malty bread flavor.  None of which is particularly overpowering but decently balanced.  Medium bodied.  Slightly cream finish with a nominally bitter finish.

Excellent example of the style.  Pours a deep red/brown, thick, creamy light brown head.  The aroma is beautiful, caramel, brown sugar, malts, bread.  The flavor follows, but is less sweet and more bready than the aroma implies.  The mouthfeel is thick and creamy, very appropriate for this style.  The finish is very low in hop bittering, but leaves a fleeting but pleasant aftertaste.  Excellent beer.
Pours a clear dark brown with beige head.  Aroma of soy sauce, roasted malt, fruit.  Taste of roast malt, fruit.  Roasted taste lingers.  Very syrupy, to be expected.
Pours dark brown with a foamy quickly fading beige head. Aroma is apple, nut, and roast malt. Taste is roast and sweet dark fruit, molasses also. Finishes with light roast bitterness.
Pours a beige head and a deep brown body.  Smells of brown sugar and soy.  Flavor is much the same.
Dark brown color.  Aroma is of yeast, malts, and with some soy sauce and dried fruit undertones.  Taste if of yeast and barley.  Its similar to a brown ale.  Has a nice bite in the end.

(16.9oz bottle) pours a dark clear chocolate w/ hints of ruby. Nice light tan head that has good staying power. Nose is toasted brown sugar, sweet malts, and belgian  candi sugar. Taste is cocoa, roasted malts, dark lightly sweetened chocolate and has a creamy finish thats slightly bitter but pleasingly so. Very drinkable and delicious.
Large bottle. Pours dark brown. Taste of caramel and molasses. Very good. Me likes.
Extremely full body and long lasting flavor.  Unfortunately, its not a flavor that I care for.

Deep russett brown.  Dense white cap of foam.  Aromoa of freshly lautered malt, slight alcohol, raisinetts.  Flavor of fresh bread, malts, very cleam fermentation.  A slightly lighter mouthfeel than other doppels but a good example of the style.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2009 On tap at Papago.  Pours clear dark brown with a thin tan head.  The nose is caramel, dark fruit and roasted malt.  The taste is dark fruit, cocoa, roasted nuts and toasted malt.  Medium fairly creamy mouthfeel.  Decent.

A truly unique and exceptional Doppelbock that goes with a more stout/porter malt than the typical caramel and burnt sugar malts found in other brews of this style. Aroma is brown sugar emitting from a dark amber color and small, white head. The flavor is what makes this DB stand out, slightly smokey with a 86% cocoa dark chocolate aftertaste, ok so maybe not that much but it is pretty heavy, where some DBs serve up a range of smooth malts this one has some edgier tones that no doubt makes it stand out above the rest, most of the rest that is. The Korbinian is a medium bodied beer that will leave you thinking you drank a light rauchbier but will make you wanting more.

Bomber.  Pours brown and orange, with a fluffy large beige head.  Yeasty aroma with a bunch of raisins, plums, overripe banana and marshmallows.  Palate features crisp carbonation and a very dry finish.  Flavor has ripe banana mixed with a malty, caramelly sweetness.  Lots of ripe dark fruit in there, golden and red raisins especially.  Finish contains dry cocoa, chocolate and vanilla.  Overall I appreciated the complexity of this brew, but I think the ripe-fruit sweetness is not appropriately balanced in my opinion.

Yet another Vegas trip brew

The labels various brown colours makes you think dark and thick before you even open the bottle. Pours out a nice thick light brown cap (fades a bit quicker than I hoped) on top of a nice clear dark mahogany brew that looks ooooh soo good. Right off the bat there is a weird, pungent smell here that shouldnt be - kinda like rank meat, something quite funky - fishy? I have no idea what this is. It is there sniff after sniff. Its a pisser because the aromas beyond that are quite nice: heavily roasted malts - super dark, molasses, raisins, prunes, maybe toffee. Dammit - I cannot get beyond this bizarre, disturbing smell. The taste is excellent but oddly enough Im finding something related to the aroma I dont like... aarrg. Dont matter much cause this tastes so fine: chocolate, roasted malts that are so damn thick, hidden sweetness - once i really noticed it it was obvious how it was fused throughout, almost something smokey that quickly vanishes, light spice that is not licorice, a perfect tasting bitterness, a concentrated dark orangy flavour in the back ground. Dammit - what isnt in this beer? HA! Ive just had a flashback to the soy sauce that I tasted sooo much in Sam Adams Tripel Bock - I think this is a prominent feature of the mystery smell and taste. Yes, Im getting more convinced. Full bodied, so very smooth in my mouth - absolutely soothing, slightest of carbonation. Finishes strong and memorable with a fruity hop and heavy yet gentle malts. This is an excellent beer. My mouth feels kinda like an ashtray. Wow. Bumping up the marks.... this should be higher than Ive given it but that characteristic of the aroma keeps it down. If anyone reads this and can explain that, please let me know. Nomad by Maiden blasting in the background. Good times. Get a hold of this brew and give it a go. Cheers.

500ml bottle from Binnys in Orland Park. Pours dark brown with thick tan head. Aroma is rich with malt, caramel, toffee, and dark fruits. Flavor is malty with the sweetness of toffee, caramel, brown sugar and some dark fruits. Nice mouthfeel. Very solid dopplebock.
Brown sugary smell and taste, moderate sweetness and carbonation. Thin lacing. Ruby red color. Not my favorite doppelbock or Weihenstephaner, but above average overall.

500ml bottle. Rich dark brown with a pillowy tan head that is well compacted. Looks robust and has a deep rich aroma that hits you as soon as you pour it. Aroma of dates, raisans and caramel and a strong flavour and aftertaste. Well rounded and other good offering from Weihenstaphaner.

Hazy brown in color with a small off white head.  Aroma of chocolate/caramel, some bread/yeast, some biscuity munich malt.  Taste has a good deal of munich, chocolate, and some caramel malt.  Smooth, malty, and somewhat rich, a medium full body with a hint of some hop bitterness in the finish.  very good.
Nice dark brown with an off white head.  Dark roasted malt aroma with floral notes a bit of dark fruit.  Sweet complex flavor with a long malty finish.  One of my favorite doppelbocks.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2010 One of my favs...Pours a dark brown, with thick tawny head that laces. Aromas of roasted malt, dark fruit, toffee and molasses. Flavors range from roasted malt(some smoke), raisin-light plum, chocolate, maple, little caramel, and light bitter hop finish which last along with the choco/malt. Very complex, wish it had more body (as it is medium) and maybe more bitterness on the finish. Otherwise one of the best in the style!! Perfect with a cigar, might I suggest Punch EMS, or if you have the means Patel Vintage 1990(red ring(not torpedo))

Bottled 50cl. Courtesy of joss. It pours a mahogany beer with a nicely lasting beige head. Malt accentuated nose with hints of rasins, mothballs and candy sugar. Sweet. Malty vinous taste which is also fruity (apple) with hints of mothballs. Low bitterness. Pumpernickel sneaking in before a mediocre finish. Thanks a lot joss!

Pours a velvet black smooth body with a thick, reasonably stiff off-white head--imposing in a Schneider glass...floral, malty balance--a bit of berry dances with a soft hops bouquet... complex, definite presence of banana, clove and caramel... soft, thin, warm mouthfeel; light for a doppelbock, almost with a weizen lift--the aftertaste is appropriately warming...smooth and deceptively soft--a pleasure to taste with a balance of malty solidness and and wheat in the teeth...a perfect treat for an unseasonably humid evening in May, refreshingly versatilefor spring, summer or fall...

Tasted 6/24/09.  500ml bottle.  Filtered with a deep very dark ruby amber hue.  Clinging khaki head.  Sweet nose with hints of cookies and caramel.  Cinnamon toast and maple syrup.  Diverse, yet faint aromatic emanations..  Medium to full bodied with a nice sticky plummy flavor.  Lotta dark fruit and a creamy texture.  Roasty and toasty, with that sticky sweetbreads flavor.  Alas, a bit o the butterscotch. Age?  Beefy caramel note. Touch cocoa and fudge.  This is everything Ive come to expect from this style.   Malt dominant with a minuscule amount of hops.  This is a good beer.  And really, who doesnt like a good Doppelbock?

Pours a translucent but very deep brown with a small off white head. Aroma is caramel, malts, rasins and a touch of metal. Flavor is chocolate, rasins, metal, caramel, fruits, esthers, a tad metallic and a touch of smoky ash. Sweet and slightly syrupy mouthfeel with a metallic tinge in the finish but highly drinkable and balanced.
smooth, malty, rich.  little bit of a bad lasting aftertaste.  carmally, good example of the style.
On tap at Mahars. Pours very dark with a thick head. Aroma is sweet and tangy. Flavor is yeasty, wheat ale with a huge bite, hefe with balls!

Bottle.  Pours a large, frothy, pitted/craggy, light brown head.  Dark brown body is a clear ruby when held up to light.  Smells of dark malts - caramel, prune and raisin.  Also present in the flavor, along with a touch of bitter cacao/dark chocolate and miscellaneous fruit - maybe some esters from fermentation.  Alcohol presence is minimal, warming.  Low hop presence; just enough to keep the malts in check.  Medium-full body, light carbonation.  Tasty beer.

Bottle, Johns Grocery, Iowa City. Deep brown pour, lots of light tan head that fades away fairly quickly. Inky raisin and milk chocolate aroma. Soft chocolate flavor with sort of an iron/chalk edge. A bit of lingering raisin. For all the sweetness, it still presents a little thin. Not bad, but leaves me a bit indifferent.
Bottle at Farina in Albuquerque.  Aroma is toasted malt; flavor is light raisin peel, the same roast and light caramel.  Not as rich as Blockhead, but certainly a great example of the style.

Pours a dark brown with a moderate tan head; decent retention and lacing.  Aromia is sweet malts, is per the style.  Flavor is equally sweet and malty, with caramel and clover honey.  The sweetness is balanced just a bit by some coffee bitterness.  Thick, full mouthfeel that is still very smooth.  A very nice example of a dobbelbock.

Appearance:  Pours an amber brown with a 1/2 inch of dense, sudsy head.

Aroma:  Bready malt, and a little bit of brown sugar sweetness.

Taste:  Caramel malt, bready malt, plum,  and hop bitterness in the finish.

Mouthfeel:  Creamy and thick.

Overall:  A flavorful, well balanced Double Bock/Doppel Bock.

Bottle from total wine.  Pours a dark brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma is malty and delicious.  Lots of caramel, toffee, dried fruit and brown sugar.  Flavor is sweet and totally malt driven.  Raisins, toffee, light roast.  Really a good beer.  Dont know why it took me so damn long to drink and rate it!

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2010 Bottle poured a clear dark brown with a quick dissipating head.  Swore the aroma was of bath water, but maybe I had a tainted glass (so Ill trust the aroma notes of others).  Malt, caramel, coffee flavor.  Medium bodied, no carbonation.  Had a second on tap.  Poured hazel brown with a medium tan head.  Caramel and toffee notes with a wisp of sugar.  Flavor much the same as the first but had additions of yeast, dough, and light spice.  Much better second time around.

Big, dark brown pour with tan filmy head. Caramelly aroma with notes of tobacco, toffee and roasted malts. Flavor is mostly roasted malt, toffee, caramel, some coffee notes, some fruit, a little weird finish. A hearty, nice mouthfeel.  Good, but not great.
This opaque brown ale poured with a fizzy beige head that bubble away. There is a treacle aroma and a hearty roasted malt flavor with a raisin finish.
Pours cola brown with tan head. Caramel and raisin aromas. Flavors of toasted malts, caramel and dark fruits. Medium to full body with minimal carbonation.

50cl bottle. Pours cloudy dark red-brown with a moderate tan head. Sweet woody fruity burnt caramel aromas. Taste is malty burnt molasses with fruity toffee undertones and a warming mildly spicy and alcoholic finish. Thick creamy mouthfeel. Very filling. One for a cold winters night. A fine example of the genre.

Pours a dark brown having a healthy looking light brown frothy/thick head. Aroma is very malty with notes of toffee, raisin, caramel, and hints of dark fruit. Flavor is rich and creamy with malt all around. Starts with hints of raisin then moves into a little caramel , toffee and molasses. Sweet and semi milky. A very good doppelbock.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2016 500 ml bottle from Liquor Barn (Fern Valley); shared with my Boo. Aroma: Dark, spiced German bread with caramel drizzle. Appearance: Cola dark red-brown pour with soft carbonation holding up a foamy tan head that, for the most part, endures. Flavor: Matches the nose mostly; the finish lingers a bit, and is not bitter at all. Palate: Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, lingering finish. Overall: A high quality Doppelbock, and due to its availability, one that has surely inspired many clones. Would recommend again and again.
Smells sweet and carmely.  Taste is malty, nutty and a little spicy.  Mouthfeel is less carbonated than I expected but extremely smooth.  This is a quality doppelbock.
Bottle pour.Sweet wood caramel and molasses  flavor,nose is almost identical.Easy to drink not thin either,well balanced instead.Really good doppelbock.

500 ml bottle.  Deep stained glass brown color.  Big, foamy head.  The aroma is all out lagery, sweet with a caramel funkiness.  Smooth and creamy on the palate, this goes down oh so easy.  Toffee and butterscotch tones.  Pretty sessionable ABV keeps it light and drinkable.  No real hop character.  Excellent beer.
0.5l - Dark brown liquid under small, light brown head.  Wood and bread on a sweet smelling nose.  Creamy, oaky, vanilla palate, a little sweet but fitting with the style.  A nice bock.

16.9 oz bottle-Clear light brown color w/almost no head & good lacing. Rich roasted malt aroma; taste didnt really deliver. Had some malt, some roasted nuts, but it was kind of boring. Seemed kind of flat to me, needed more sweetness or malt flavor or spice or...something. Short flat finish.

Bottle. Pours with a large light brown head and a clear ruby-black colour. Great toasted-caramel and light resinous hoppy aroma.Understated crystal malt taste with a subtle spiciness and a residual sweetness and a slight alcoholic warmth to the finish.

Pours hazy dark brown with a nice inch-thick tan head that lingers.  Nice bright floral aroma, nutty and sweet.  Solid malt flavor with great background of nuts, caramel, coffee and a nice warming kick of alcohol.  Slight bitter aftertaste, but a nice clean finish.  A very smooth drinking experience, always wanted more after each sip.

Bottle (thanks bierkoning!). Very dark brown color with a medium, stable, beige head. Nice caramelly aroma with some bread and quite a bit of nuts. Sweet firm malty flavor with roasted dark bread, caramel, some toffee and light alcohol notes. Nice heavy mouthfeel. A very good winter beer.

pours a clear reddish-brown, thick but quickly-receding beige foam
very malty aroma, tons of caramel, faint lemons
very smooth silky texture
flavor is fairly mild, mostly just the same caramel and malt, no discernible hops and just slight alcohol in the finish

Bottle from Whole Foods.  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Sweet, malty aroma with caramel and roast.  Flavor is malty and sweet with dark fruit notes (plum, fig), caramel, alcohol, and slight hop bitterness.  Smooth, fairly full palate with a little alcohol warmth.  Overall a phenomenal example of the style.  Spaghetti pairing was not great though.

dark brown with medium tan head.  moderate carbonation.  nose of caramel malt.  flavor is of caramel malt with some burnt notes from kettle caramelization.  hop bitterness makes it reasonably balanced.  not too much residual dextrins doesnt leave it overly malty and cloying.  the finish might be the best part, being very clean for such a large beer.  very good, one of the best doppels i have had

Beer #100! Poured a very dark chocolate black with a hint of red. Smells roasty and bitter. The taste is all dark chocolate, smoke, slightly sweet slightly bitter. Very well rounded, not too much of anything stands out to me. A good beer.
Bottle. Brown and poured with a small head. Nutty and malty with a pleasant aroma upon opening.Very easy to drink considering its fairly high strength. Nice.

Bottle. Pours a very deep dark brown with a nice frothy tan head that leaves good lacing. Sweet and malty aroma with caramel, dark fruit, chocolate, raisins and some nuttiness. Smooth and very rich flavor of sweet caramel malts, molasses, chocolate, raisins and brown sugar with a medium to full body and has a sweet dry roasty finish.   Awesome brew

Wow, this is liquid bread crust- everything about it scream, smells, and even looks like a mouth of bread crust. This would go so well with pb&j it is not even funny. No seriously, Im not laughing. Why are you? Stop Laughing! $2.99 per 500ml bottle at Gulf Liquors, Miami Beach

Bottle: Poured a deep Burgundy color bock with large dirty brown color head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of banana ester with some dry fruits notes. Taste is also dominated by some dark fruit taste with ester of banana and some sweet malt. Body is about average with some creamy notes and good carbonation with no distinguishable alcohol. Well done but it would have been even better to get a fresher bottle.
Great Doppel.  Aromas of grilled oranges/lemons. Bitter roasted malts, plum and citrus on the palate.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2010 500ml bottle from Warehouse Liquors in Spring Hill, FL. Pours dark brown with a thin beige head. Aroma is licorice, raw honey, mollasses, toffee and some malts. Flavor is mollasses, honey, licorice, burnt toffee. Bit of a nasty aftertaste. Sticky, medium mouthfeel. This isnt bad...but I just dont think Im a fan of this style.

16.9 oz bottle, via EDA.  Pours a nice dark chestnut brown body with a one inch frothy beige head that slowly settled to a thin film.  The nose is sweet lightly roasted and toasted malts with a touch of nuttiness.  Rather smooth flavor with just a little bit of residual sweetness, not enough to be sticky or under attenuated tasting.  Light roast coffee, toasted malt, a bit of some plum like fruitiness on the back end.  A little bit of noticeable alcohol and husky graininess on the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a fairly clean finish, moderate soft fizzy carbonation.  Overall a pretty nice beer.

Color is a deep dark amber with good carbonation and a thin head.  Aroma is a fruity roasted scent.  Taste is roasted, sweet and smoky.  Starting with a medium body it goes down easy with a sweet nip on the end.  Finish comes on with some dried fruit ( raisin and prune ) then a roasted flavor with a touch of smoke and very easy bitterness.  Overall this is a tasty brew with a nice balanced flavor.
Bottle. Drank with bman1113vr. Pours a dark black with a off white head. Smells of semi sweet chocolate, raisins, bananas and molasses. Tastes of unsweet chocolate and raisins.

Bottle. Pours with a light brown, bubbly head and a very dark mahogany body. Good lace.  Aroma of bananas, rummy, alcohol, patent leather, chocolate, raisins, cinnamon, molasses, and caramelized mini wheats. Taste chocolate, light coffee roast, wheat, banana, vanilla,and sweetness. syrupy mouthfeel and light bubbles.

16.9 oz bottle from Market of Choice. Dark amber pour with a nice small beige colored head. Very pleasant roasted caramel flavor with some molasses and chewy nut flavors. Very nice nutty and caramelly aroma as well. My third straight winner from the oldest brewery in the world.

Has roasted and caramel malt smell.
Pours a dark amber color that appears clear with a rich eighth inch biege head. Too dark to see anything.
Smooth roasted caramel taste throughout not burnt.
Moderate to full bodied and resiny not syrupy or watery with lively soft carbonation.
Very smooth, with a hint of being chewy, a session Doppelbock that is not to sweet.
Deep copper with a decent sized beige head. Aroma is of chocolate, dark fruits and caramel. Taste is of caramel, prune and alcohol.
Dark and rich. Malt molasses and some alcohl tones. Some bitterness in the after taste

Pours dark brown with a fizzy, beige head; looks very much like a cola in the glass.  Malt aromas of hazelnuts and toast with a hint of dates; no hop bouquet. Thankfully not as sweet as many doppelbocks but not as complex either.  Caramell and prune up front finishing with leather, molasses and grain husk qualities that are not entirely pleasant.  A bit of an aged hop flavor, perhaps?  Body is thin for the style.  I really want to like this beer, but the finish is just not tasty.

(Bottle at Weihenstephan Berlin on 2009-02-04) Dark reddish brown and clear. Long lastin tan coloured head. Chcolate, malts and caramell in aroma. Full bodied and thick palate with little carbonation. Cholate, malts, caramell and bitterness in balanced taste. Chocolate and bitterness in aftertaste.

Pours a reddish brown with a small head. Light molasses and brown sugar dominate the sweet, but dry flavor. Theres even some dark fruit in there. Supremely drinkable - very smooth, and dry enough to keep it from being too sweet. Very flavorful. Nice!

Pours a dark copper tinted brown with a tall, creamy tan head that has good retention. Aroma is dark malt, roast, toast, lots of caramel, butterscotch, some candy and dark fruit notes as well. Flavor is sweet wheat bread right away, quickly followed by sweet malt, a little roast, chocolate, candied pit fruit, date nut bread and some overripse bananas. Finish is suprisingly bitter hoppy and sudden, almost off putting at first as the transition is unexpected but it works fairly well after a few swallows.

500ml bottle served in a hefe glass. Poured a beautiful mahogany with three fingers of tan head. Malty aroma with molasses and dark fruit. Also some noble hop aroma. Rich malty flavor with some chocolate and more molasses. Not overly sweet. Very smooth and creamy Nice malt complexity. Very drinkable. I liked this a lot. If you are a fan of German malt flavor, you should try this.
bottle 500ml shared 290109 with FatPhil &Anna EXP 07.05.09 deep copper very heavy roasted malts at first then bready sweet crisp bite hidden alcohol. Very tasty more please!

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2009 500ml bottle (Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam) - shared with mirjukka - thanks!
Deep red, slightly hazy, no head. Heavy sweet malty aroma. Massively malty bready sweet palate. Some biting sharp hops. Mellows to green buds. Covers 7.2% well. Big, bold, and beautiful. More please :-)
A great sweet aroma, deep mahogany body and dark tan foamy head, and fine roasted malt, coffee and nuttiness in the mix.  A very nice double bock.

This is one of those that left a weird impression on me the first time around, I couldnt put my finger on it at the time, but it is very nice this go around. 
The beer pours a beautiful deep ruby color with a nice tight tan head leaving a good lace. Aroma is sweet, nutty, very malty. Flavor is far more intense than the aroma but follows suit. Immedate notes of molasses, some good roasted malt, and a lot of nice nuttiness working around in the background. There is a mild bitterness which seems to come more from the roastedness of the malt, but works with the bit of hops that is present. Palate is very slick sort of oily but plesant never the less.

Strong flavor and strong hops for a German beer.  Even a little heavy on the alcohol.  Warms up to more carmel and roasted malt flavors.  A lot of unique characteristics not found in other Dopplebocks.  Enjoyable..

Caramelly malty aroma with spicy hops, smooth creamy aromas.  Pours a dark amber with a thin white head.  Smooth and malty, caramel malts, traces of molasses, spicy hops, very very smooth.  Very enjoyable and easy to drink.  A really nice dopplebock.

Pours the darkest ruby, nearly brown unless held up to the sun. Creamy head with lacing the dissipates in a beautiful way. Chocolatey-appley malt aroma is mild, with some molasses in the background. Medium bodied with a soft palate. At 7.4%, its a drinker, and of course were harder on brews than most people. This is better than 98% of what I could get going out in the Springs, just dont get alot out of this one. I respect the Weihenstephan brewery, but this wont ever be their calling card.

Bottle from BevMo costing $2.69.  Poured a rich red with nice foamy white head and good lacing. Nose of malts and ripe fruit.  Smooth mouthfeel.  Very rich flavor with lots of fruit flavors. Bitter finish. Very nice beer.

Nice dark red color, transparent. Smells a lot like cereal or grains, grape nuts. The taste is very malty, some fruit, clean. Germans arent usually my thing but this is a very interesting beer and one I will re-visit in the hopes of learning something.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-12-2009 01:39:51

Bottle into stein. Pours a clear, dark brown, with hints of mahogany around the edges, and a small, fluffy khaki head on top that lingers. Bit of effervescence visible as well. Nose is restrained but delicious - molasses, bread crust, a bit bready, toffee. Taste is delicious - molasses, hints of dark fruit and brown sugar, a light roasty note hinting at dark breadcrust but with no acidity at all - rich and bready, sweet but balanced. Finish is long, hints of bitterness, reminiscent of rye bread and molasses. Mouthfeel is almost perfect - smooth but with a light, fluffy carbonation that is close to flawless. Superb beer.

Pours brown with a red hue, dark but glowing and see-thru, with a medium off-white frothy head that dissipates quickly into a thin fine cream.  Nice roasty grassy aroma, lightly rich, raisins, nutty and very German.  Yummy first taste, quite enjoyable, dark roasted malts without any sign of being burnt, some chocolate and caramel, raisins, roasted bread, grassy, rich and very smooth, just sweet enough.  Almost a 5 in palate, super smooth, light sharp fizzy carbonation, almost creamy, nice soft mouthful overall.

Draft at Paradiso.  I could have drank this for hours.  Faint aroma of sweet chocolate, and a nuttiness.  The flavor is where this one got me.  Touches of toffee and lots of fruits, raisins, plums, vanilla, and caramel.  Something about this one really got me.
On draught at Birreria Paradiso.  Classic doppelbock with a bitter hops background, malt foreground, and decent slight bitter finish.

Deep brown pour with thick and creamy light tan/slightly yellowish head.  Malty caramel, some wheat, and notes of chocolate and hazelnuts on the nose.  Stronger chocolate and nuts on the palate.  Great long finish.
Rich brown colour. Thin, creamy head. Full aroma of roasted malts with hints of cocoa. Warming malty flavour. Lingering hint of cloves stays on the tongue accompanying the warming alcohol.

500 mL. Pours a deep clear red with a modest cappuccino head that settles to a nice film. Not too much lacing. Aromas of caramel, overripe fruits, and for some reason chlorinated pool water- yuck. Taste is rye bread with lots of molasses and cocoa powder. Long, dry, bitter finish. 7.4% is nicely hidden. Somewhat of a disappointment after traveling far and wide to find this sucker.
A deep mahogany color with nice creamy off-white head.  A solid caramel malt aroma.  Roasted malt flavor with a caramel finished.  Creamy mouth feel with a dry malty finish that lingers quite well.

Clear dark amber with a huge beige good lasting head. Sweet aroma with overripe rotten fruits, roasted malt and caramel notes. Sweet flavour with roasted malt, rye bread, caramel and overripe fruits. Warming alcohol towards the end.

Pours an extremely dark ruby into the glass with a small white head.  Aroma is rich with molasses and nutty notes.  Nice malty flavor with roasted grain on the finish.  Very smooth mouthfeel.  Really lovely.

Darn good beer. Big, rich and balanced as only the Germans can do. Lusciously creamy beer full of malt but never overly syrupy or sweet. Glowing magenta brown with a frothy head and moderate lacing. Sweet and malty aroma with subtle hops. Huge malt-centric complexity. Oak, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, nutty grain and soft yeasty dough. Unobtrusively bitter finish. The beer coats the mouth pleasantly but never stickily, and the feel is velvet smooth. I dont know about the bread in a mug cliche, but it is certainly a chewy glass of delicious malt.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2009 50cl bottle. Very dark ruby, firm lacey beige head. Buttery, rye bready roasted aroma, little vinous fruits, rowanberry, coffee and nuttiness. Roasted malty flavor, sweet rye, berries, herbal licorice finish. A tad alcoholic, smooth full palate. A great dobbelbock.

16.9 oz bottle.  Dark purple brown with a thin beige head.  Nose is grape, toast, caramel and some honey.  Enough to chew on without feeling heavy.  Light carb.  Taste is caramel and raisin with hints of tobacco.  Nice burnt sugar finish.  Very good.  I was surprised at how much i liked this.

500ml Bottle: Aroma of malts, slight smoke, nuts, woods, roasting, slight peat, light wort, and fallen oak leaves.  Poured brown/dark amber in color with a small, dense, tan head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Lightly sparkling.  Ok lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of malts, nuts, fallen oak leaves, light caramel, slight toffee, slight roasting, and slight brown sugar.  Medium body.  Smooth, lightly syrupy texture.  Average texture.  Lightly sweet, nutty, malty finish.
Bottle No head, bllack and filtered. Nose of yeast and wheat. Taste of chocolate, roasted malts, wheaty, sweet and sticky. A bit too carbonated and fluffy. Good but not great.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Sampled at the Great Decatur Beer Tasting Festival in Georgia on 10/18/08. Deep amber in color. Aroma - Very malty. Taste was complex. Malt, caramel dark fruit - raisin and plum. Smokey and spicey. One of my favorites of the day.

Bottle from BevMo Mission Valley.  Deep hazy brown color with a small beige head.  Nose of candied dark fruits (plums, figs, raisins).  For some reason I caught some dry dog food in there??  That really turned me off of this beer, I have tried in the past and remember really liking it.  I might have gotten an old bottle.
500 ml bottle shared during Nertz party.  Nice malty aromas.  Prune and brown sugar.  Sweet flavor with more dark fruits and some dust.  A very decent Doppelbock.

Oh yea, cute dark, like root beer pour without a head. Has that lucious dunkle or dark lager aroma with a mild volatile eythanol olfactory. Chocolaty initial flavor impact evolves into a stronger alky palate. Each swig comes across the same way, chocolaty to an american malt liquor evolution. At first I didn’t think this was 7+% but now I am a believer. oooowahhh.  Yowser bowser, as Mario or Luigi would say. A dark lager that finishes like a malt. Good change of pace. Detectable miniscule carbonation creaminess. I almost want to give it a mid taste rating but its just a tad too much alky for this pale yelow lager lover. Alky bite remains a little rude at the end.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottled: Mahagoni color, aroma is light roasty, wood barrels, malt and caramel, Flavor is malty, round and full bodied. Alcohol, caramel notes and some molasse. Light dry, light roasty finish. Full bodied, but all in all common bock.
500 mL bottle from Wine Warehouse, numbered 7068. Pours a dark brown with a medium head. Heavy dark fruits in the aroma with some wheat and soy. Taste is dark fruits, soy and rye bread. Full bodied.
(Bottle).  Sweet caramel malt aroma.  Reddish amber body, small creamy tan head.  Sweet fruity and caramel malt flavor.   A bit too sweet.   Surprisingly light finish.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of dark bread, toasted and mild coffee, moderate hops of herbs and resin, light earth for the yeast, and notes of raisin, soy sauce, toffee, honey, and cola. Head is fizzy, light brown with fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is brown. Flavor starts heavily sweet and lightly acidic, and finishes lightly sweet and bitter. Palate is medium to full, between creamy and syrupy and has a lively carbonation. Nice deep malty aromas and a sweet flavor makes this a great Doppelbock for me.

500ml bottle. BB 30.07.09.
Pours a beautiful ruby-highlighted deep bronze body with a dense, creamy light-tan lace clinging to the glass.
Big malt aroma; rich cocoa, roasted nut, melanoidin graininess, cream, dark plum and vinous dried fruits.
Rich lenghty palate, low fluffy carbonation, sticky texture with drying dark chocolate tannic quality. 
Wow! This beer is just chock-a-block with delicious malt character; dark chocolate, caramel, honey, nuts, cocoa, figs, prune, raisin, subtle smoke and liquorice. Drying finish, dried fruits and cocoa lingers.
This is great! Big, succulent, malt-driven lager. Cleaner and less complex than big dark Belgians, but certainly is enjoyable!

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2009 Clear dark mohogany pour with fair light tan head.  Dark fruit aroma with caramel malt.  Flavors of honey, raisin, malt, and plum.  There is even some meatiness in there!  Creamy medium body with a sweet malty finish.  Fantastic doppelbock and a great label to boot!

pours a murky brown with a cream head.  Aroma is caramel and raisins.  Taste Is more dark fruit, chocolate, vanilla and a nice bitterness on the end to cut some of the sweetness.  Not a huge dopplebock fan but this is one of the best I’ve had.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2008 On tap at tap house in Seattle
V - dark brownish black with little head
A - coffee and lite chocolate porter aromas
T - nice coffee balanced with malts

In short: An overly sweet and slightly fruity big bock 
How: Bottle, consumed fresh a few days after purchase
The look: Very dark ruby body topped by a beige ring of foam
In long: Crisp molasses (and lots of it), raisins, toffee, some black liquorice, some tobacco.  Somewhat sticky.  Starts off ok but syrupy sweet and by the end of the bottle I was sick of it.  Might please those with a sweet teeth.  But I must admit not being a big fan of Doppelbocks, Ive never been to a Doppelbock game cheering Go Doppelbocks Go!.
nice and rich, with lots of caramel and a mild amount of hops, it oozes substance with lots of room left over in the after taste. a great beer to add to your collection.

Maybe it was a poor decision to try the Ayinger Celebrator and then try this.  94% really?  Aroma of malt and hops with chocolate eclipsed by the smell of something missing.  Taste is full and typical of a good German Doppelbock but I couldn’t help but notice the thinness of the flavor.  Overall, not terribly overwhelmed.  Great mocha chocolate color with deep amber head.

Poured to a dark brown with medium thick off-white head that lingers til mid-glass and leaves okay lacing. Nose is a pleasant malty mix of earth scents, roasted nuts and smoky wood. Mouthfeel is full and slightly chewy, and the flavor is malty sweet nuts, chocolate, caramel and a hint of the 7.4% alcohol as the beer warms. Rounds out to a nice long finish.

A pleasant experience.
Such a nice aroma of malt, deep caramel, and biscuit. FLavour is full bodied, and rich. Loads of caramel malt, and bready malt. Wicked doppelbock, one of the best in the genre.

Honey roasted malt aromas.  Dark brown with a thick head.  Very tasty flavors of malt, brown sugar, honey, Palate is solid and just rich enough to stay balanced.  Well rounded and drinkable. Will definitely need to revisit this one.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2008 A juggernaught of beers. Embodies the spirit of the dopplebock, pouring a dark brown wand topped with a thick fluffy tan head. Strong malty aroma and flavor. Nice malt presence sits on the back and sides of the tongue for a long semi-sweet finish. A bit of raisiny dark fruit, and a subdued bitterness shows up in the finish. Every bit a contender for Ayingers dopplebock. Hurray Reinheitsgebot!

Pours a dark brown with a dark tan head.  Resembles a stout.  Taste and aroma have hints of chocolate malt, roasted nuts and coffee.
