Reddish brown, lush, perfect head that never fades away.  Aroma of bread.  Flavors of pumpernickel, a touch of toffee, surprisingly dry finish.  Never would have picked this for a doppelbock, as I actually enjoyed the beer.

A big malt treacley nose hits when you first open the bottle subsiding to a mild fruitiness. Colour is a royal dark bourbon red with a medium small medium lasting tan head. Body is medium fullnes, lowish carbed, clean and non-coying. Flavour is primarily medium low sweetness caramel malt with touch of lingering fruitiness. Mild sweet and dry roasted malt reasonably clean aftertaste. Alcohol very well masked.

Bottle:  Apparently Im the only one who thinks this, but the aroma seems to a combination of salt and grass.  Smells almost like a soup but I cant think of what kind (its on the tip of my tongue).  Very strange.  Pours a dark transparent reddish-brown with a tan head that dies rather quickly.  Decent lacing. Very malty taste.  Very, very slight bitter finish.   Very smooth mouthfeel.  Somewhat malty aftertaste.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2007 2007-10-03, draught at Freaking Frog, Las Vegas, 7-4-6-3-13=33Dark chestnut color. Aroma of unmalted cereals and malt. Good body strength, good caramel flavor, but the final is a bit stale. In the final there is basically dark caramel.2004-05-16, bottle, 5-4-7-4-13=33Beautiful amber color. Light aroma (malt, caramel) more interesting flavor, with a good malty structure and a balanced, long final.

Cola like coloured body with a large lasting tan coloured head. Aroma is most certainly malt, caramel and slightly roasted. Taste follows the malt aroma with more malt again, a touch of sweetness, alcohol is hidden and a creamy oily texture. Cheers!

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2014 Fruit jam gelling with caramel, cooking luxurious malt cookies... A silky mouthfeel and perfectly leveled residual sugars force the eyelids to slowly close every other sip... Earthy connotations add depth in the finish for a most elegant Doppelbock, whether in the bottle or on tap at the brewery restaurant...

Clean amber body with a fluffy tan head. Aroma is strong and sweet with big bursts of malt. This is a very malty beer, smells like a can of malt extract. Flavor is massive, full of malt and alcohol. Sweet almost cherry flavors in the highly alcoholic finish. This is one prize of a beer. Overall, this is an awesome beer. It should be slowly enjoyed from a snifter. Bottles are the perfect size too. Outstanding!!!
Deep amber color with a beige head. The taste is strong malts with some sweetness and slight alcohol in the finish.

I would probably rate this one second only to the Celebrator amongst the doppels Ive sampled. For fans of smooth, malty beers, dont miss this one. Creamy, with a sweet (but not overly so) carmel-like flavor. Pours a deep brown hue, with a foamy head and good retention. Almost perfect mouthfeel. Another great beer from a great brewery.

Yeast, malt, dark fruit, hickory and marzipan in the aroma. Clear, very dark brown but not opaque. Thin off-white head that recedes to cover. Mildly sweet bock flavour with an earthy roastiness and light raisin flavour. Pleasant lasting aftertaste. Mildly astringent. High carbonation. I had higher hopes for this one. It was very good, just not fantastic. Enjoyed with MartinT and Rastacouere. Bottle.

Big foamy and sticky off-white head over a clear ruby brown body. The aroma consists of sweet maple, toffee, roasted and smoky malt, dark and red fruits with prominent character(cherries, plums) and an enticing earthiness. Its very fruity and almost smoky, but actually not that spectacular after a few sips, earthy grape bubble gum if such a thing exists. Body could be a little thicker, but carbonation is moderate and appropriate. Basically, the palate doesnt seem to reveal the promised secrets from the sniffing, but this is still a very good beer if not great.

Deep dark Bavarian doppelbock.  Significant alcohol (7.4% abv).Cola color brown-red with a roasted barley malt and light hop aroma.  Medium-dry slightly hoppy flavor with medium-full mouthfeel.  A full off white head forms with lace falling in curtains.

Ruby red when held up to the light with a foamy beige head and a slightly off dusty grain nose.  Creamy mouthfeel for a doppelbock.  Lots of malty sweetness and very easy to drink, but not much else to this beer.

bottled: got this on recommendation from the waitress. didnt know what i was getting due to a heavy german accent. did understand this to be their best selling 'dark'. what i didnt understand is that it was a doppelbock. on taste alone i would of said....dunkels.  mahogany color with a tan creamy head.  nose is mostly malty sweet. same with in the mouth following through. some plum and raisin aftertones with sweet choc malt being the dominant man. tastes like a typical dunkels to me, but its a doppelbock. not big enough in my opinion for a doppelbock beer.

OK head on a hazy amber reddish body. Sweet malty and fruity aroma with notes of oranges, brown sugar and rye. Rye and malt in the flavor - very sweet for a Doppelbock. A quite mild and easy drinkable beer.

Poured with a nice reddish, muddy brown. Candy corn and some smoke dominate the aroma. Flavor is bubblegum, wheat and, maybe, wood? Interesting, but it is still fairly light in flavor and body for a dopplebock. I would get this again.
Dark reddish brown coloured. Malty aroma with notes of apples. Flavour is sweet and very malty.
This was a good beer, but not the best doppelbock I have ever had.  The body seemed a bit thin but everything else seemed right up to par.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2011 I have grown rather fond of this one over the years though I need to get back and rerate it sometime as my tastes have changed since this one was entered. +++ Sampled from a 16.9 oz brown bottle this beer pours a rich mahogany color with a large tan head that lingers. There is a rich, dry, malty scent. The texture is very smooth with a creamy, malty flavor that lingers on the tongue.

Very dark amber and slightly hazy. Nice head, but it quickly pops away. Cakey-yeasty nose. Soft and very creamy texture -- nice! Malts were fairly sweet, a little roasty, woodsy, damp and earthy. Hops were a little fruity (dried apricots), herbal, and grassy, with a healthy amount of bitterness that easily kept up with the big malts. Good beer.
A brown beer with a beutiful brown head. The aroma is lovely malty with a slight sweetness. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of dry wood and roasted bread. A lovely beer.

Dark, clear garnet. Big foamy head--very little lace. Malty nose. Somewhat sharp carbonation. Medium bodied with loads of dark malt flavor. Very lightly sour. Finishes clean with some lingering molasses/brown sugar sweetness.

sweet, nutty & caramel smells-- with a tinge o' alcohol.  sweet, smooth, roasty...  a nice finish. roasted plums, caramel.  a bit of iron in the finish, but not enough to be annoying.  not very bubbly.  i really do like this beer.
Sweet smell.  Nice, deep red/brown color.  Malty flavor with some plum, raisin, prune taste to it.  Very easy to drink.  Tasty Doppelbock.
Draft.  Aroma is all malt - toffee, dark dried fruit, and hints of coffee.  Dark red-brown in color, OK head.  Flavor matches the aroma, on the sweet side.  Full-bodied and smooth.  Very good.
Oddly refreshing for a doppelback.  Tastes classically German, malty and roasty.  One of the better doppels that I have tried.
Starts lightly and finishes strong.  a lot of the flavor is on the back end. ginger, chocolate, and roasted malt are the primary elements.  definately a good one to enjoy on a cold night by the fire.

Huge lasting head, glossy molasses-colored body.  Very sweet malty-earthy nose, rasins & caramel & ginger & chocolate.  Bit too simple in the flavor department, but I love a very sweet, full-bodies doppel with lots of chocolate at the end and a big finish.  Lovely, great for a Wisconsin winter.
Dark reddish brown body with a tan head that disappeared too quickly.  Could not distinguish the aroma except to say that it was sweet.  Full to the mouth with some caramel notes.  A delicious beer.

A malty aroma wafts from my glass.  This beer is a deep dark amber color, it shows fairly clear when held up to the light.  This beer is just wonderfully malty.  Lots of caramelized malt taste, as well as a bit of chocolate.  There is a certain fruitiness here that is more from the malt presence than any yeast character.  This is a nice clean lager that really lets the malt character shine through.

Keg, Amsterdam BBF2003. Ruby red, good creamy beige head and moderate condition. Good bocky melanoidin and roast barley notes in the nose, smooth mouthfilling toffee and cream in the mouth and a sweet finish with a delicate prickle of hop bitterness. At a festival that celebrates just one basic beer type, it becomes difficult to find favour or fault with any one beer. Imagine twenty Dutchmen playing the same tune on a variety of trumpets, some play the tune as written, some with a flourish or two. Then up stands a German, produces a tuba and plays the same tune in an Umpah stylee and everyone takes notice. A big brash tuba of a beer in a sea of trumpets.

Pours a reddish cola color, settles a bit darker with a nice clear gem-like glow, thin tannish head breifly makes an effort to stay but fizzes quickly down to a thin hazy skim and ring, lace in minimal spots. Aroma is a bit faint of toasty sweet malts and dark fruits lending some plum, raisin, dates, and dried apricot. Taste is a bit more filling, starts a little weak and thin but begins to gain malty weight with a nice toffeeish sweetness and finishes strongly with a nice mixing of dark fruits of plum, raisin, dates, and figs giving way to a little chewy caramel lingering finish which is super smooth and creamy. Nice finish on this. Theres a bit of a metallic twinge in the midway parts but is barely noticeable and appears mostly at the front of the tongue and the lips. Feel is close to medium with a light silken creamyness that floats through the palate with ease and the finish is quite nice with a light building of chewy sweetness. A soild dopplebock by any standards, good stuff.
Aroma has chocolate bannana and toffee.  The flavor has much the same with a smokey hint.  The mouth-fell is a little light.  The beer is very smooth.  A great doppelbock.
Smooth and toffee flavored all over, a tiny hop bite (could be more!) - thinnish, handles the 7.4% well, not overly sweet - a very good dopple.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Immediately upon opening the bottle, this beer's big aroma hits the nose, with prune, raisin, toffee, caramel, and bread (cookie dough?).  I recommend a "swirling" before pouring Korbinian- the initial part of the bottle poured clear and red, and the thin tan head quickly disappeared.  The remainder of the bottle, though, was full of yeast sediment, and upon pouring it into my glass, a thin white head reappeared.  Flavor is all one can expect from a good doppelbock- being especially heavy on prunes and toffee.  A malty delicacy and a neat addition to my bottle collection.

Number 400! Pours a deep browned red. Nice tall tan puffy head. Nose is sweetened with malt. There's something else hiding in the nose, maybe caramel or toffee and almost a sour-ish hint. Hard for me to pick out. The taste is good. Sweet malt with a chocolate and oatmeal cookie mix. Smooth as silk finish Will look towards having this with my yearly Oktoberfest gathering.
Just tried this beer last night,  Wow, I just loved it.  Slightly sweet,  maybe chocolate or toffee.  I will need to more to be more desriptive.

Sugary caramel malt aroma, some brief hints of raisin, date and perhaps licorice, along with a faint yeasty banana component.  Deep reddish brown color and a slight head, fed by very tiny bubbles.  Flavor is decidedly malty and sweet, plenty of maple sugar, caramel and toffee, with a bready, nutty and very gently hopped finish.  Thick palate, bordering on syrupy, with a low level of effervescence.  Shouldn't this be known as "Korbiniator" or something?

This one is cloudy brown with lots of floaties and a significant head that dwindles to a thin layer of film. Aroma is sweet with a huge malt profile. Full bodied with a creamy feeling mouthfeel. Flavor is super strong and malty with a definite alcohol presence. There's a ton of malt in this brew and not much else.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: A very carbonated brew.  MAlty aroma witha  touch of alcohol.  Body has a sweet maltiness with a taste of alcohol.  Decent but nothing great.

Sweet malt aroma, dark dark amber in colour with a large brown head. Very malty and sweet, slight bite of alcohol in it, caramel and a bit of toffee with slight bitters that hang on the roof of your mouth. Thick in body decent none-the-less.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2009 Deep brown beer with good active head, towering even.  The aroma is strongly alcohol-sugared.  Indeed, the flavor is rich and thick with cooked sugar, nuts, roasted malt.  Even some raisin here.

Bottled: pours a dark beechnut with a full taupe head that diminishes quickly.  Full malty aroma with plenty of hazelnuts, milk chocolate and banana.  Fairly thick mouth feel that is clean and full of flavour.  Luscious chocolate, a hint of campfire smoke, wood and a plethora of nuts.  A hint of cascade hops evident in the finish, though not much.  Overall a beer I would drink very often.
Nice dark color with a fine head.  Good malt and carmel in the nose.  Full body.  thick and chewy.  Good dark beer.

Decent dopplebock.  I think this brew is suffering from comparison as I sampled Celebrator Dopplebock yesterday.  On its merits though Korbinian smells of malty molasses.  A bit one dimensional compared to others.  Flavor is good, just doesn't have the complexity I was looking for in a dopple.
Bottle.  Dark mahogany color with a foamy light brown head.  The aroma is malty with some caramel and  molasses.  Mostly a full maltly body with a little nut and toast.

Frothy beige head that diminishes quickly. I am bad with color, but this one is cola dark.Aroma of caramel and roastiness. Flavor of caramel and malt and finishes sweet with slight bitterness. Overall a very malty sweet and drinkable beer that hides the alcohol very well. I may need more lessons in the ways of dopplebock.
Beautiful frothy, dirty white head. Malts are everywhere, aroma, taste, down to a full bodied palate. Not too sweet, a light mouthfeel. Outstanding.

Nice amber,brown color mild head that little staying power,Malty sweet aroma with a slight fruity side to it.The taste was all most more then i could handle,malty sweet with hints of caramel and mild fruit tones very smooth and a malty after taste that was fantastic.There was nothing in this brew to dislike and everything to like,i wish i had more then the one beer but i know where to get more and thats the main thing.The alcohol in this brew appears to be well hidden you don't really detect it much but you feel it after half the bottle is gone.Just a fine Dopple all around.

This was an interesting beer. Not what I was expecting, because it was a little light bodied for a duppelbock. This beer is a dark amber color; it pours a nice head that vanishes quickly. The aroma and taste if this Korbinian, is a malted caramel. If you see it at your store pick one up and give it a try.

Sweet malty, molasses like aroma with a hint of nuttiness. Little to no head on top of a beautiful nut brown body. Excellent malty flavor - just the right amount of sweetness. Alcohol is hidden extremely well - appears just a bit in the aftertaste though. Overall, an excellent dopplebock - hard to find - even where other Weihenstephaners are sold.
on draught at the Anthill pub, early 2003. This is a very nice doppelbock. Dark brown body w/ a tan head. Nice malty taste, smooth & sweet

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2003 Wow!! What can I say except this is one heck of a good tasting Dopplebock!! This beer poured a light brown to a tan medium head. Dark brown body. Some carbonation was observed. It had a dark brown body. The taste was simply excellent! It has an extremely smooth taste, no bitterness or aftertaste. Darn, this was one heck of a good drink!! More please?

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 This brew poured a large creamy head of light brown finely sized bubbles. It has an extremely nice malty aroma that is very pleasant to the nose. The body of this beer is simply beautiful. Its a dark almost opaque brown color with some carbonation rising up the side of the mug. I loved the taste of this brew with elements of caramel, malt, and spice. It was extremely tasty. The head left a ring of lacing around my mug as it receded. This is an extremely good example of why I like Doppelbocks so much. Very smooth, delicious and one of the best brews I have had in a while. Einemal bitte! Once again: Im Himmel gibt es kein bier darrum trinken wir es heir! Translation: In Heaven there is no beer! That is why we drink it here.

This beer pours a dark amber/brown color with a medium head and almost no lacing.  The aroma was slightly malty with hints of fruit.  The taste was very smooth and sweet with a thick roasted taste to it.  The drinkability is just a medium because it is very sweet and very thick.  It is quite enjoyable, but I don't think I could drink several in a row.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2004 Pours a roasted caramel color with a nice light tan head.  The aroma is nice blend of sticky, dark fruit, caramel, chocolate, and dry grain.  Smooth and clean mouthfeel.  The flavors compliment the aroma nicely with plenty of great fruit, plum, raisin, cherry and fig.  A wonderful value and a wonderful surprise.

I was surprised by this cheap bottle!!  Dark brown with a sweet nose of thick malts and a little hint of the alcohol.  Very smooth and sweet without going overly nasty with sweetness.  Thick and malty, with more alcoholic notes as it warms up. Veery nice, I'll remember this one next Winter!

An excellent Doppelbock.
This is right up there with Ayinger's Celebrator Doppelbock.
Nice "Dark Strong Beer" from the "Oldest Brewery in the World." Great smell, good head, wonderful, germanic finish. Not the best double bock I've had, but in the top ten.
UPDATED: JAN 3, 2016 Nice huge head that rises above the rim of the glass; deep rich brown color; malty smell, almost like molasses; smooth texture; pleasantly bitter finish.

Light roasted and vegetable aroma but not annoying. Dark brown color, light brown head, fair lace. Light roasted, light sweet, dark caramel flavor. Short finish. Very nice dunkles starkbier but a doppelbock???

Pours a deep, reddish-brown, with an ample, creamy head. Mild, spicy hop aroma, plenty of mellow roasted malt and some  root or bark accents. Buttery, sweet flavor, smoothly carbonated. Finish is OK, clean but, undistinguished. Overall, a nice, easy drinking beer.
Deep dark ruby brown color. Malty and fruity aroma. Medium to full bodied, malty and fruity flavor (pear and banana). Some roasted malt and coffee. Just a hint of metal in the aftertaste.

Beautiful Mahogany color with a huge off-white head. The aroma was sweet...clove...bananas...caramel...malty sweetness...tobacco. The flavor was similar to the aroma with a little alcohol added. Extremely enjoyable doppelbock.

This one pours a very dark amber color with a medium sized, off-white head that lingers. It also has particles of yeast floating throughout the beer. The aroma is weak and I detect only a bit of malt presence. Medium bodied with low carbonation, the flavor is malty sweet with some hop presence in the finish and a nice lingering malty sweetness. This one gets better and better as I drink it. Good, strong maltiness, perfect carbonation, and a slight hop presence make this a good doppelbock.
This one was nice, but not what I had hoped for. A very nice dark coloration, but the aroma is lacking. Flavor is nice and full, but lacking in real character. Overall, good, but not great.
A bit strong it is of good quality. I got a buzz from one bottle. I think it is ok but too heavy for me and a bit bitter

Dry, musty aroma of caramel, dark chocolate, and a touch of nuttiness.  Medium to dark brown colored with a small ring of foam.  Good, well-rounded flavor of roasted nuts and chewy malt.  Lot's of malt in this one, which makes me a fan.  If it were a tad thicker, darker, and sweeter, then it would rival Celebrator.
A malty behemoth of a brew. Worth the years-long wait.  Just a shade beneath the mighty Celebrator for dopplebock supremacy, but man this is a fine beer by any standards.

Dark oak color.  With thin white head that quickly fades.  Big malt nose, with a type of syrup sweetness.  Some soft notes of hops found in the end.  Not really thick, but not watery by any means.  Sort of tastes like plums, raisins, and caramel mixed together.   An interesting mix of flavors.
Brown body with healthy tan head.  Medium sweet aroma, some dark fruit (raisin), smidgen of caramel.  Taste is sweet, grape, malty, and somewhat cloying.

there's that tinny metallic thing again. aroma AND flavor had a tinge of tinny. i LOVE their dunkle hefe and their regular hefe, but this was a bit of a disappointment.  comparable to (albeit much better than) a dark lager like st pauli or becks.
Almost no aroma. Dark brown hue. Nice head. Very slightly bitter.

Not much to mention as far as aroma goes, not a bad aroma just not a noticeable one. Dark brown appearance. Malty flavor with hint of roasted grains and very slight hop prescence.  Medium on the palate with nice carbonation. Very drinkable beer.
Brown,thin tan head.Great malt nose.Carmel malt flavor throughout

Dark red/brown coloured. Chocolatish head with medium lasting. Aroma is sweet, fruity and malty. Flavour is malty and has fruitnotes and is medium spiced. Flavours is not as distinct as I had hoped for. There is some alcahol burn in the aftertaste. Not the most complex dobbelbock, but still a good beer.

Tried for the first time the other night and i had no idea what it was when i ordered it. Smoky and burnt flavor, intermixed with sweet malt. Quite excellent. Very appealing except the large amount of debris at the bottom of the bottle, which left me puzzled. Oh well, still good.
Very well put together.  Ordered at brewery, it was my biggest surprise of my trip.
Dark brown with a nice off-white head. Malty flavors with a nice warming effect due to the alcohol.

Foamer! Luckily I didnt spill a drop. Dark brown, not the black I was expecting. Nice small-bubbled off-white head. Aroma is fruit past its prime. Flavor is light caramelly malts, no real hop presence but some odd funky spice. A bit sweet and syrupy. Mouthfeel is lively with constant steaming bubbles.

pretty sever rotten fruit aroma. prety soft and sweet with lots of chocolate bullets. i agree with austinpowers that it tastes a little more like belgian beer than german thanks to some icing sugar sweetness and plenty of caramelised pear. very smooth and drinkable but lacking that certain something to make it really interesting
Malty aroma.Amber appearance.sweet malty flavor with a slight chocolate finish that gets drowned by sweet malt.It seemed like more an Octoberfest than a Dopplebock.

Deep amber color, large foamy head. Aroma is very malty. Big malts, slightly sweet. Caramel and toffee then hop spicy. Nice balance. Big malty beer. Warming. Robust flavors. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is dry. Aftertaste is malty, with a lingering malty sweetness. Nice.
clear dark brown colour. Malty aroma; bit sweet. Taste is quite malty, caramel. Bit bitter. Smooth palate. Good bock.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2003 Sampled at Utrechts Bokbierfestival Dark brown color. Malty aroma. Roasted malty taste. Bitter palate, like a lot of German beers. Rerate Better, maybe perfect temperature. But this bock is quite good actually. Almost a combination between the dunkel and a bockbeer. Malty, bit fruity and also heavy on the stomach.
One of best bocks i know... Well, second to the Utrechts Bock of course ;-)

Sampled draught at Thembi, Maastricht.
Mahogany with brief beige head. Neutral nose. Sweet and malty with syrupy mouthfeel and loads of cramell and toffee in the finish. A solid and warming bock, but not one that offers that little extra.

yep, this is one malty thick brew - and the alcohol warmed my body and spirit.  Lighter cola color, medium fizzy head.   a little bit tangy, toffee/caramel, raisin, tiny bit of alcohol flavors.  This was very good, but a bit overwhelming in the malt department.

Bocky, dark syrup aroma.  Good label, bottle (ahem, homebrewers) and deep tea-brown beer with camel-colored head. The actual flavor and palate were a little disappointing given the nice aroma nad presentation. Dry, grainy and a little tinny.  Dilute molasses-like flavor.  Thinnish.
Brown pour with the slightest hints of red.Big tan head that is gone in a flash.Aroma is reminding me of toasted raisin bread. Nice malty backbone. Sweetin the middle with a little bitter at end.
Very strong beer, neverhteless, it has great taste and aroma.

chestnut roan, wisp of haze like warm breath on the glass. the head was a dollop of burlap colored suds, with thick fancy lace like the filigreed rails of a french quarter balcony. lush aroma bespeaks holiday baked goods: raisins, rum and brown sugar, pecans and carmelizing  crusts. sweet and smooth; and while its true more bitterness would make it stellar, this is a grand brew. apparently my gastronomic  mood converged with the brewers intent on this one- with fortuitous and rapt harmony. yeehah!
dark ruby-brown colour, fine head and a nice lace, butter and caramel aroma, very malty, sweet and heavy, long malty finish

what a great beer plenty of malt enough hops to offset the sweetness of the malt. drank this at the brewery while sitting in the outside beer garten while sipping on beer schnapps made at the brewery (this is not a re-rate but i had the wrong brewery info)

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2011 Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy/creamy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is dark brown.

Aroma is moderately malty (toasted bread, caramel, nuts), lightly hoppy (flowers), with notes of banana, orange peel, light note of cinnamon.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, syrupy/watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Kind of syrupy sweet, but its quite clean tasting and there is enough finishing bitterness to keep it drinkable. Brighter aromatically than most of the other common German doppels.
Rich caramel - toffee - biscuit aroma.  Dark brown with red tinting, large beige head.  Buttery biscuity flavor.  Definitely malt oriented, almost unbalanced but not quite.
Great yeast flavor, very malty and sweet.
This doppelbock had hints of belgian-style dubbels and singels.  Odd, really.  However, I quite liked it for its uniqueness.  OK.
A Salvator clone, IMHO...but isnt that a good thing?  Buttery malt flavor overwhelms the senses.

Deep garnet in color, huge biege head and sheets of lace. Nose is caramel, roasted grains, fruity, somewhat sweet. Start is sweet, the top light to medium, the finish is hop spicey, tart, dry, acidic, and is quite robust. The addition of the 7.4 percent ABV, does make it unsuitable for the Palate Challanged Light Beer crowd.

Pours with a dark amber, caramel color. Produces a thin beige-colored head of foam. 
Aroma: Sweet; layers of malt, nut, dark fruit and molasses. 
Flavor: lively mouthfeel through having a moderate amount of carbonates; toffee, caramel, plum and raisin flavors threaded by nuts and coffee. Round, silky, lingering finish. Bitterness value: 32.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2004 A rich, complex Weizenbock. Deep amber color with a thick white, durable head. Initial nose is that of ripe dark fruit, molases and caramel. Silky smooth palate which is dominated by the malts. Some mild banana esters make their appearance, but palate is one of dark fruit, spice and sweet molasses. Alcohol cuts down the sweetness a bit to prevent it from being cloying. A real classsy brew!!
Nice weizenbock, sort of like drinking two or three dunkelweizens at once. Almost chocolatey.
It seems to defy categories; tastes similar to a wheat doppelbock, somewhat sweet, but lager-like.

Beautiful amber color, nice head.  Sweet malty aroma, no hop aroma detectable, but alcohol present in the nose.  Very wheaty sweet taste that starts sweet and stays sweet.  Decent, but slightly disappointing.
Spicy and fruity. Add a 7.4ABV and you have the recipe for a great Doppel! Another great product from Bayer.

Tastes like 80% bock, 20% wheat.  This is listed as a weizenbock, however the style on this site seems much more appropriate.  Strong roasted caramel and plum aroma, with heavy plums, figs, prunes, and dates flavors and a fruity banana/apple finish.  Develops a scotch-ale character as it warms, making this a unique, albeit slightly underachieving brew from my favorite brewery.

This beer has one of the best aroma Ive run across - caramel, toffee, maple and a hint of chocolate. The first sip was almost as complex.  Lots of depth and body.  The 7.4% alcohol punch hides in the spicy finish.

Behind a slightly acrid nose lies a beautiful, slightly malty beer with hints of fruit and caramel. There was a slight hint of a metallic taste in the first sip, but that quickly dissipated. Left practically no aftertaste, surprisingly for such a strong beer.
Nice and malty, slightly sweet, and fruity. Very interesting, lighter but yet still a robust flavor. Definately worth a try.
Malty aroma, slight caramel flavor with a few hop notes
